course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Questions of Humanity in World Literature
course.description: This course attempts to, through the eyes of literature, explore and discuss the major themes that encompass many aspects of humanity and the society and world that we live in - human existence, relationship among self, society and the state, the meaning of war, identity in the change of time, romance and love, documenting history, and finding one's voice in the colonial and postmodern world. Students will be guided through a critical reading of the representative literary works from both Western and Asian traditions, and attention will be paid to the ways in which different literary forms help convey and reflect on these ideas and themes.

reviews.author: 快樂肥仔
reviews.comment_content:
The Existential Question – “The Book of Ecclesiastes”
Self and Community – The Plague, Albert Camus
Power to the State – 1984, George Orwell
Humanity in Holocaust – Diary of Ann Frank, Ann Frank
What Money Can Do – Capital, John Lanchester
Utopia/Dystopia Future? – The Fat Years, Chan Koonchung

For those who are not very good at English or whose native language is Chinese, it might be a bit difficult for them to finish this course since all the readings are in English (but you can also look for the Chinese version of those books except Capital).
reviews.comment_teaching: There are lots of in-class discussions and the professor would randomly pick someone to answer her questions.
reviews.comment_grading: I think I treated this course seriously and I finished all the optional writing tasks as well, but I got a B+ LOL.

reviews.author: mmhleung
reviews.comment_content: A wide variety of topics relating to identity, community, power etc... About 1-2 weeks spent on each topic, and a new reading on every topic. These topics are not necessarily difficult, but they do challenge you to think, and many times you can easily second guess yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor draws attention of the class very well; participation and differing views from different students help make the content more interesting. She tries to engage as many people as possible and encourages people to voice their own opinions. Uses ppts, but those are not helpful, and you can learn most through listening in class.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fairly lenient. As long as you fully understand the readings, the quizzes and projects shouldn't be too difficult. For participation, speak up a couple times every class and you will get a good mark. For the final project, you can consult the professor or TA, and they'll guide you through it. As far as I know, most groups got an A for their project.
reviews.comment_workload: A lot of readings to complete every week; you need to refer to them for class participation and during your projects. Attendance is 10% of the grade, and another 25% is in-class participation, pop quizzes and a few easy assignments. The other 65% is made of 2 projects: an individual mid-term paper and a final group project (you can choose your own topic), which consists of both a paper and a presentation.
